vignette:
A black male in his early 20s with a remote history of depression as an adolescent and current cannabis use presented following an assault while incarcerated. He was found unconscious with mental status changes and brought to the hospital. Initial examination and work-up revealed right-sided periorbital edema and ecchymosis. The patient was arousable to noxious stimuli but would quickly return to sleep and was not interactive during multiple examination attempts. The emergency department staff believed there was a volitional component to his lack of participation in the exam, as he would push away from providers as they examined him or lie unresponsive. At one point, the patient was able to ambulate briefly while in the emergency department (although he ran into several objects) and tolerated an oral intake challenge with juice. Over the course of 5 days, the patient was returned to the emergency department by the facility four more times due to concerns that his mental status was not improving. The facility reported the patient was unable to attend to his ADLs. He was seen to be withdrawn, not eating or drinking, and toileting on himself or the floor. Additionally, guards (as he was incarcerated for part of his hospital admission) reported that he would occasionally speak to family members and staff. However, when he was offered paperwork to sign himself out of jail with an ankle monitor, he only gazed at the officer without speaking.

Urine toxicology was positive for THC and a negative blood alcohol level. He was found to have ketones consistent with starvation ketosis. Lumbar puncture revealed CSF cell count with six total nucleated cells present, <2,000 RBC, 54 mg/dL glucose, and 39 mg/dL protein. Meningitis/encephalitis panel for 14 common viral and bacterial pathogens and antibody testing for West Nile Virus was negative. CT of the head showed no fractures of the face/vertebra and was negative for other acute findings. EEG was read as consistent with a normal drowsy state. MRI of the brain, both with and without contrast, showed a cerebellar developmental venous anomaly but no acute findings. A neurology consult was obtained. His neurologic exam was noted to be variable, with poor participation despite repeated prompting, making full examination difficult. He responded to pain equally in all extremities, demonstrated no abnormal movements, had 2+ reflexes symmetrically, and normal pupillary response. Neurology ultimately felt that his LP, MRI, and EEG were unremarkable, and his symptomatology could be explained by postconcussive symptoms.

Once the patient was admitted, he was initially treated with a trial of Modafinil for suspected postconcussive syndrome, to which there was no response. On Day 6 of his hospitalization, when the psychiatric consultation service reconsidered his disordered behavior, psychomotor retardation, and speech with consideration for the presence of catatonia, the question of “volitional” inactivity took on a new meaning. There were numerous catatonia signs present to variable degrees: mutism, decreased oral intake, negativism, withdrawal, and decreased spontaneous movement. No automatic obedience, ambitendency, or rigidity was appreciated.
diagnosis: Catatonia

vignette: A 12-year-old male with no specific birth or medical history became concerned about lower abdominal distention and began reducing his food intake 3 months prior to consultation. He exercised obsessively according to his food intake. Although he was considerably losing weight, he commented that his belly was fat and did not want it to get any fatter. Body image disturbances and anxiety regarding being overweight were observed. During his initial consultation, he was very lean, with a body mass index (BMI) of 11.5 kg/m2. He also had sinus bradycardia with a heart rate of approximately 40 beats/min. We attempted to improve his weight with enteral nutritional supplements while identifying underlying diseases by head magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and abdominal ultrasound. However, he became disoriented and was emergently hospitalized 7 days after his first visit. On admission, he was 145 cm tall, weighed 20.9 kg (BMI: 9.9 kg/m2), and presented with impaired consciousness with Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) E3V4M6, bradycardia with a heart rate of about 40 beats/min, and slow breathing with a respiratory rate of about 10 cycles/min. Blood gas analysis and blood test revealed hypercapnia, hypoglycemia, and elevated levels of creatinine, blood urea nitrogen, and transaminases. His movements were slow but not paralytic and his cranial nerves were normal.
diagnosis: Anorexia nervosa with focal cortical dysplasia
model_thoughts:
Let me analyze this clinical case vignette systematically.

**Data Extraction and Organization:**

Demographics:
- 12-year-old male
- No specific birth or medical history

Timeline and Presenting Concerns:
- 3 months prior to consultation: became concerned about lower abdominal distention
- Began reducing food intake
- Exercised obsessively according to food intake

Key Clinical Features:
1. Cognitive/Behavioral:
- Concern about abdominal distention (body image disturbance)
- Food restriction
- Obsessive exercise
- Commented belly was "fat" despite being considerably lean
- Did not want belly to get "any fatter"
- Body image disturbances
- Anxiety regarding being overweight

2. Physical Findings at Initial Consultation:
- Very lean appearance
- BMI: 11.5 kg/m² (severely underweight for a 12-year-old)
- Sinus bradycardia (~40 bpm)

3. Course:
- Attempted nutritional support with enteral supplements
- Became disoriented 7 days after first visit
- Emergency hospitalization required

4. Physical Findings at Admission:
- Height: 145 cm
- Weight: 20.9 kg
- BMI: 9.9 kg/m² (extremely low, life-threatening)
- Impaired consciousness (GCS E3V4M6 = 13)
- Bradycardia (~40 bpm)
- Slow breathing (~10 cycles/min)
- Lab abnormalities: hypercapnia, hypoglycemia, elevated creatinine, BUN, transaminases
- Movements slow but not paralytic
- Cranial nerves normal
- Head MRI and abdominal ultrasound ordered (to rule out underlying diseases)

**Diagnostic Reasoning:**

Primary Consideration - Anorexia Nervosa:
This case strongly supports Anorexia Nervosa based on DSM-5-TR criteria:


The patient meets all three diagnostic pillars: severe caloric restriction resulting in critically low BMI (9.9-11.5 kg/m²), intense fear of weight gain coupled with compulsive exercise to prevent it, and significant body image distortion where he perceives his lean abdomen as fat. The restricting subtype applies given the exclusive use of food limitation and excessive exercise without binge-purge behaviors. This presentation qualifies as extreme severity given the BMI falls well below 15 kg/m².

The constellation of medical findings—bradycardia, hypoglycemia, elevated renal markers indicating dehydration, transaminitis suggesting hepatic stress, hypercapnia from respiratory compromise, and altered mental status from metabolic derangement—all align with the physiologic consequences of severe malnutrition. While anorexia nervosa is the clear primary diagnosis given the psychological features combined with these complications, other conditions warrant brief consideration in the differential.

OSFED could apply if full AN criteria aren't met, though they appear to be. ARFID lacks the body image disturbance and weight-gain anxiety that distinguish this case. Body dysmorphic disorder might coexist but doesn't explain the eating restriction pattern as well. OCD features could underlie the compulsive exercise component. Anxiety and depression are common comorbidities in eating disorders but aren't the driving pathology here. Delirium from metabolic disturbance should be ruled out as a primary cause of the disorientation.

The medical workup ruled out other underlying conditions, so the focus narrows to the eating disorder and its direct consequences. The primary diagnosis is Anorexia Nervosa, Restricting Type, given the severe restriction, body image disturbance, and medical complications including the delirium secondary to metabolic derangements like hypoglycemia and hypercapnia. Anxiety about weight is a core feature that warrants documentation as a secondary diagnosis. relevant here. The core diagnosis is clearly Anorexia Nervosa, Restricting Type (F50.01) given the severe restriction and compulsive exercise without binge-eating behaviors. The delirium from metabolic disturbances secondary to the eating disorder would be F05. While there are obsessive features around exercise and body image concerns, these are better understood as manifestations of the eating disorder itself rather than separate diagnoses—the body preoccupation is intrinsic to AN, and the compulsive exercise patterns fit within the restrictive subtype presentation. Anxiety symptoms may be present but likely stem from the AN rather than constituting an independent anxiety disorder. Anorexia Nervosa, Restricting Type is the primary diagnosis given the clear DSM-5 criteria. Delirium from metabolic derangement would be secondary. The anxiety about weight appears integral to the eating disorder rather than a separate condition. The compulsive exercise pattern seems driven by the eating disorder itself rather than independent obsessions, so OCD may not warrant its own diagnosis. I should reconsider whether additional comorbid conditions are truly present or if they're manifestations of the primary disorder. The primary diagnosis is clearly **Anorexia Nervosa, Restricting Type** (F50.01) — all diagnostic criteria are present: critically low weight (BMI 9.9-11.5), distorted body image despite being severely underweight, intense fear of weight gain, and active restriction combined with compulsive exercise.

**Delirium due to another medical condition** (F05) should be considered as a secondary diagnosis given the disorientation and altered consciousness likely stemming from severe metabolic derangements including hypoglycemia, hypercapnia, and organ dysfunction. Additionally, anxiety symptoms warrant documentation, though they may be secondary to the eating disorder itself rather than a separate anxiety condition. The delirium appears secondary to an underlying medical condition rather than primary. Anxiety symptoms are present but seem intertwined with the eating disorder presentation. ARFID and Other Specified Feeding or Eating Disorder don't fully capture the clinical picture since the patient meets criteria for anorexia nervosa with its characteristic body image disturbance and restrictive patterns.

1. Anorexia Nervosa, Restricting Type - F50.01
2. Delirium due to another medical condition - F05
3. Unspecified Anxiety Disorder - F41.9
4. Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder - F50.82
5. Other Specified Feeding or Eating Disorder - F50.89

vignette:
We report on a 35-year-old female with a history of schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type, and cocaine use disorder, with multiple previous psychiatric admissions, who was brought to our hospital's crisis unit after her parents called police, complaining that she had become aggressive and was “acting delusional” during an argument. According to her parents, the patient had demanded a DNA test to prove that her parents were not her biological parents and that her son was not her biological son. One week prior to admission, the patient's parents had reported her missing when she “disappeared” from their home soon after being discharged from our hospital following a similar presentation. Prior to admission, the patient's medications included lamotrigine, clonazepam, and long-acting injectable aripiprazole; however, her adherence to treatment recommendations was poor.

Although her parents claimed that she resided with them and her 2-year-old son, the patient endorsed a recent history of homelessness lasting several months. The patient said that during this period of homelessness, she had been sexually assaulted by a stranger in his hotel room. Collateral revealed that per court order, the patient's continued custody of her son was contingent on her adherence to psychotropic medications and inpatient drug rehabilitation. The patient admitted to using recreational drugs frequently over the past 6 months, including crack cocaine, which she stated she had used during the 1-week interval between hospitalizations.

During her initial mental status examination, the patient was poorly groomed, uncooperative, intrusive, and irritable. Her speech was pressured, and she described her recent sleep as poor. She commented that she intended to become pregnant and to sell the baby to an agency for $6,000. She made religious statements about “being fruitful and multiplying” and admitted to recently engaging in hypersexual behavior, explaining that “I have boyfriends on the streets.” She underwent testing for sexually transmitted infections, with reassuring results. She declined voluntary inpatient psychiatric admission and was subsequently screened and committed. We discontinued clonazepam at the time of admission, and we restarted the patient on lamotrigine, adding oral aripiprazole to supplement her long-acting injectable aripiprazole.

During her hospitalization, the patient faced several barriers to efficient psychiatric stabilization. First among these was her insistence on refusing any medications that might cause weight gain, including olanzapine. She endorsed allergies to haloperidol, risperidone, lurasidone, and lithium, with symptoms such as “anxiety,” “eye rolling,” and “facial twitching” in response to these drugs. Because she was adherent to oral lamotrigine and aripiprazole, we chose not to seek treatment over objection to administer a stronger antipsychotic medication that would also serve as an effective mood stabilizer. On hospital Day 4, the patient appeared virtually in family court, where she received an ultimatum to cooperate with treatment recommendations in order to maintain custody of her son. Nonetheless, she remained adamant about not being placed on “weight gainers,” stating that “I can have nine more babies. I want to be sexy.” On hospital Day 6, she tested positive for COVID-19 and was quarantined for 10 days on a medical floor. Her respiratory symptoms included cough and rhinorrhea, and she continued to display manic symptoms, including elated affect, hyperverbality, grandiosity, religious preoccupation, and inappropriate laughter. She exhibited behaviors suggestive of sexual preoccupation, such as raising her shirt during interviews to reveal a protuberant abdomen and repeatedly endorsing a desire to “stay sexy.”

After her quarantine, the patient returned to the psychiatric unit with her manic symptoms unresolved. On hospital Day 17, she requested a pregnancy test due to concerns that she might have become pregnant because she “had sex with a bunch of guys because I was homeless.” The patient seemed reassured when we explained that her admission pregnancy test was negative. We ordered a new quantitative β-hCG test, which was likewise negative. On Day 18, the patient received a maintenance dose of long-acting injectable aripiprazole. On Day 19, she complained of abdominal and back pain, stating “I've been in labor since last night.” She elaborated that “I can feel the head in my crotch” and “when I lay on my back, I feel the little hands and feet.” She also stated that her “water broke” and her “mucus plug broke.” The patient exhibited several physical signs and symptoms of pregnancy, including a distended abdomen, intermittent “pulsating” bilateral lower abdominal cramps, and sensations of fetal movement. In addition, she endorsed amenorrhea for the past year, except for some “mild spotting” three weeks previously. Convinced that her two recent pregnancy tests were “false negatives” and frustrated that members of the treatment team did not believe she was pregnant, she threatened to sue the hospital for failing to provide obstetric care. The patient lamented that “you all think I'm crazy, but I'm actually pregnant.” At this time, she displayed an intensifying religious preoccupation and stated that she was able to communicate with angels and “see Jesus.” She proclaimed that she herself was a prophet who could interpret the “auras” of hospital staff.

The patient agreed to a pelvic exam, which revealed a distended, nontender abdomen. The uterus was nongravid. The patient received acetaminophen and heating pads, and we ordered a transabdominal ultrasound to better assess the etiology of her abdominal pain and in the hopes of resolving her condition via additional evidence of nonpregnancy. At this time, the patient began to refuse all previously prescribed medications because she believed these would harm her “baby.” She did, however, agree to begin fluphenazine elixir, which we prescribed to address worsening psychosis.

When she arrived in the ultrasound suite, the patient offered the radiology technologist four million dollars “if you get this baby right.” She became euphoric while viewing the ultrasound monitor, exclaiming “That's a head, and that's a penis!” Her speech was pressured, and she perseverated on religious themes, requesting that all non-Christian staff leave the suite and instructing staff to “resist the Devil and he will flee from you!” She also demonstrated sexual preoccupation, recalling an experience in which she had “danced after I had sex” and exclaiming about the size of her “baby's penis,” predicting that he would be “sexy like his daddy.” After the procedure, the patient happily told fellow patients that she would soon deliver another child. She said, “I have been having contractions for 19 hr. When the results come back and they find out I am not crazy, they will finally send me to maternity.”

An on-call psychiatry resident presented the radiology report to the patient on hospital Day 20. She emphatically refuted the report, articulating a persecutory delusion of a conspiracy waged against her by the treatment team. She stated that the radiologist must have been “paid off” to switch her ultrasound with that of another patient. She continued to refuse medications that she felt might harm her “baby”; however, she agreed to an increase in her dose of fluphenazine. Following this dose increase, her affect remained labile, with frequent swings between euphoria and irritability, but she ceased making comments indicative of religious and sexual preoccupation. As our hospital is a short-term care facility, we decided to refer the patient to a higher level of care facility. On the day of her discharge, the patient told a nurse that “I don't think I'm pregnant anymore; it's all the shit I have inside me,” referring to her constipated bowels.
diagnosis: Pseudocyesis
model_thoughts:
Let me carefully analyze this clinical case vignette to extract key clinical information and develop a differential diagnosis.

**Data Extraction and Organization:**

**Demographics:**
- 35-year-old female

**Psychiatric History:**
- History of schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type
- Cocaine use disorder
- Multiple previous psychiatric admissions
- Poor medication adherence

**Current Medications (prior to admission):**
- Lamotrigine
- Clonazepam
- Long-acting injectable aripiprazole

**Social History:**
- Lives with parents and 2-year-old son (per parents)
- Patient reports recent history of homelessness lasting several months
- Reports sexual assault during period of homelessness
- Court-ordered custody contingent on medication adherence and inpatient drug rehabilitation

**Substance Use:**
- Frequent recreational drug use over past 6 months
- Crack cocaine use during 1-week interval between hospitalizations

**Precipitating Events:**
- Parents called police due to aggressive behavior and "acting delusional"
- Patient demanded DNA test claiming parents and son weren't biological relatives
- Patient had been reported missing 1 week prior after "disappearing" following discharge

**Mental Status Examination:**
- Appearance: Poorly groomed, distended abdomen
- Behavior: Uncooperative, intrusive
- Mood/Affect: Irritable, later euphoric, labile (swinging between euphoria and irritability)
- Speech: Pressured, hyperverbal
- Thought Process: Perseverative (especially on religious themes)
- Thought Content: 
  - Delusions of pregnancy (pseudocyesis) - believed she was pregnant despite multiple negative pregnancy tests and ultrasound
  - Persecutory delusions (conspiracy that radiologist was "paid off" to switch ultrasound results)
  - Grandiose/religious delusions (being a prophet, communicating with angels, seeing Jesus, interpreting "auras")
  - Plan to sell baby for $6,000
- Perceptions: Somatic delusions (feeling fetal movement, "labor pains," "water breaking")
- Cognition: Not formally assessed
- Sleep: Poor
- Insight/Judgment: Poor (refusing medications, refusing to believe test results)

**Manic Symptoms Present:**
Multiple features consistent with acute mania: pressured speech, severely disrupted sleep, hypersexual behavior with multiple partners, grandiose ideation about prophetic status, elevated and expansive mood with inappropriate laughter, and impulsive decision-making. The religious preoccupation and goal-directed activity (planning to sell the baby) further support an acute manic episode superimposed on her underlying schizoaffective disorder.

**Psychotic Features:**
Beyond the somatic delusions, she's experiencing persecutory ideation, grandiose religious beliefs, and visual/spiritual hallucinations involving Jesus and angels. The pseudocyesis developed around day 19 of hospitalization and worsened alongside the religious and sexual preoccupation. Antipsychotic escalation with fluphenazine helped reduce the religious and sexual content, though she retained some delusional conviction about pregnancy until near discharge when she began questioning whether she was actually pregnant.

**Diagnostic Considerations:**
The concurrent manic presentation—pressured speech, minimal sleep need, hypersexuality, grandiosity, euphoria—alongside these psychotic features points toward schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type, which is her established diagnosis. The psychotic symptoms appear intertwined with mood episodes but remain prominent enough to suggest they're not purely mood-congruent. Her multiple prior admissions support this pattern. Alternatively, bipolar I disorder with psychotic features could account for the manic symptoms paired with mood-congruent delusions, though the elaborate pseudocyesis seems atypical for that presentation alone. Her documented cocaine use disorder is also relevant to consider, as stimulant use can precipitate or exacerbate both manic and psychotic symptoms.

Regarding the substance use, recent frequent crack cocaine consumption combined with her current homelessness, legal involvement, and functional decline suggests moderate to severe cocaine use disorder rather than mild. The psychotic and mood symptoms, however, extend well beyond what acute intoxication would produce, making the underlying schizoaffective disorder the more likely primary driver. A somatic delusional disorder could theoretically explain the pseudocyesis, but this too is better accounted for within her schizoaffective presentation.

The most fitting diagnosis remains schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type, given how it captures both her persistent manic features and prominent psychotic symptoms across her longitudinal history. Her cocaine use disorder warrants a separate diagnosis due to active recent use and legal consequences. Bipolar I disorder is also in the differential, though the psychotic features that persist independent of mood episodes point more toward the schizoaffective diagnosis.

Her trauma history from sexual assault during homelessness likely contributes to her presentation and should be evaluated further for PTSD or trauma-related disorder. The pseudocyesis appears to be delusional in nature rather than a somatic symptom disorder, fitting within her broader psychotic presentation.

For the cocaine use disorder coding, the pattern of frequent use over six months, use during homelessness, custody-related legal consequences, and continued use despite these outcomes points to moderate-to-severe severity. F14.20 captures moderate cocaine use disorder, though I need to verify whether this code also applies to severe presentations or if a different specifier is needed.

The psychotic and manic symptoms appear to extend well beyond typical cocaine intoxication or withdrawal timelines, suggesting an underlying primary psychiatric condition rather than substance-induced effects. This distinction is important for determining whether these symptoms warrant their own diagnosis or are secondary to another disorder. The differential includes schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type as a primary consideration, followed by cocaine use disorder and bipolar I disorder among the leading diagnoses. Looking at the established diagnosis and current clinical presentation, schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type appears most consistent with the patient's longstanding course and acute manic episode with psychotic features. The active cocaine use disorder requires concurrent treatment attention. The reported sexual assault history warrants consideration of trauma-related sequelae. Bipolar I disorder with psychotic features remains a reasonable alternative given the prominent mood symptoms, though it doesn't fully account for the baseline psychotic features typical of schizoaffective presentations. The pseudocyesis delusion could reflect somatic preoccupation within the psychotic framework rather than a primary somatic symptom disorder. Pseudocyesis here represents a delusional belief rather than a somatic symptom, so that doesn't fit. For the primary diagnosis, schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type seems most appropriate given the concurrent mood and psychotic symptoms. Cocaine use disorder should be documented as a comorbid condition. Bipolar I disorder with manic episode and psychotic features and schizophrenia remain important differentials—though schizophrenia is less likely given how prominently the mood disturbance features. There's also possible trauma-related pathology that warrants further assessment. The ICD-10 codes align: F25.0 for schizoaffective bipolar type, F14.20 for cocaine dependence, and F31.2 for the bipolar manic episode with psychosis.

Regarding the trauma history, the sexual assault is documented but without clear PTSD or acute stress symptoms, so flagging this with F43.9 (unspecified trauma- and stressor-related disorder) seems reasonable to prompt additional evaluation rather than assigning a more specific diagnosis. Alternatively, delusional disorder could be considered given the fixed false beliefs, though the mood component makes schizoaffective disorder the stronger primary diagnosis. Moderate severity fits the pattern of frequent crack cocaine use over six months with continued use despite legal consequences and risky circumstances during homelessness. The differential includes schizoaffective disorder, bipolar I disorder with psychotic features, schizophrenia, and trauma-related factors given the documented history. I'm settling on the list that incorporates both the primary psychiatric presentation and the unspecified trauma-related disorder, as this captures the full clinical picture without overspecifying diagnoses that remain uncertain. The sexual assault is documented but lacks clear evidence of trauma-related symptoms that would meet criteria for a specific disorder, so including F43.9 may not be warranted. I should consider other differentials instead.

Substance-induced disorders are worth exploring—cocaine-induced psychotic disorder (F14.959) or cocaine-induced bipolar disorder (F14.94) could apply, though the persistent symptoms and established history of schizoaffective disorder independent of substance use make these less likely primary diagnoses. Medical causes have been ruled out through testing and COVID-19 didn't appear to trigger the psychiatric presentation. Borderline personality features might warrant consideration given the impulsivity noted, though there's insufficient information for a definitive diagnosis.

The most clinically relevant diagnoses appear to be schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type (F25.0) as the primary diagnosis, cocaine use disorder, moderate (F14.20) as a comorbid condition, and bipolar I disorder with manic episode and psychotic features (F31.2) as a key differential. Schizophrenia (F20.9) and cocaine-induced psychotic disorder (F14.959) are less likely given the prominence of mood symptoms and the pattern of symptom persistence.

Schizophrenia and delusional disorder round out the differential considerations for psychotic presentations. This formulation better captures the range of possible psychotic disorders to consider in the diagnostic workup.
model_diagnosis:
1. Schizoaffective Disorder, Bipolar Type - F25.0
2. Cocaine Use Disorder, Moderate - F14.20
3. Bipolar I Disorder, Current Episode Manic, Severe with Psychotic Features - F31.2
4. Schizophrenia - F20.9
5. Delusional Disorder - F22

vignette:
The patient is a 58-year-old woman with a psychiatric history of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), major depressive disorder (MDD), post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), dyssomnia, tobacco use disorder, and alcohol use disorder in remission. Her tobacco use disorder began at age 22, and she smoked two packs of cigarettes daily. At age 46, she decreased her tobacco use to smoking one and a half packs of cigarettes daily. Two years later, she further decreased her tobacco use to smoking one pack of cigarettes daily.

Her alcohol use disorder began at age 38, and she drank a pint (473 mL) of hard liquor daily. At age 45, she decreased her alcohol use to half a pint (236.5 mL) of hard liquor daily. The following year, she decreased her alcohol use to only weekends. Two years later, she used alcohol very occasionally. At age 49, her husband passed, and her alcohol use increased to a fifth (750 mL) of gin daily. She was hospitalized twice that year for chronic pancreatitis and quit drinking after the second hospitalization.

She struggled with worsening GAD, MDD, and PTSD since age 39. At age 46, she was prescribed citalopram but did not tolerate it. At age 49, she began regularly seeing outpatient psychiatry. She was prescribed sertraline and prazosin. A few months later, her MDD and PTSD symptoms significantly improved. However, her GAD worsened, and she had more frequent exacerbations. Her sertraline and prazosin dosages were increased. She was also prescribed hydroxyzine but did not tolerate it. Additionally, she received grief therapy as recommended. Her MDD and PTSD symptoms improved significantly more, but her GAD continued to be uncontrolled. Intermittently, she would be out of her medications, and her MDD and GAD would worsen. Her PTSD was stable, even when out of medication.

Also, the patient was prescribed melatonin for her dyssomnia at age 50. Her dyssomnia was uncontrolled despite increasing the melatonin dosage. She did not tolerate trazodone. The patient was then lost to follow-up with outpatient psychiatry for 2 years and returned at age 53. Since then, she has had regular follow-up appointments with outpatient psychiatry.

When she returned to outpatient psychiatry at age 53, she had been off of all psychiatric medications. Her MDD was partially stable. Her PTSD was stable. Her GAD and dyssomnia were uncontrolled. She had resumed drinking small amounts of alcohol on occasion, about once a month, and she continued to smoke one pack of cigarettes daily. Her sertraline was resumed, and she was started on zolpidem. Her dyssomnia improved with zolpidem. Eventually, her sertraline was switched to paroxetine. After trialing multiple medications, she was started on diazepam for a short period for her uncontrolled anxiety. Psychotherapy was also recommended, but she did not take part in it. In April 2020, at age 55, her outpatient psychiatry appointments were converted from in-person to telehealth due to COVID-19 health regulations.

At age 49, the patient first noted fatigue and poor memory. At a follow-up appointment a few months later, she continued to report poor memory. A year later, she reported worsening memory, resulting in losing her keys and forgetting important dates. After that, she did not report fatigue or memory concerns for several years.

In August 2021, at age 56, the patient had mild COVID-19, which did not require hospitalization. Since then, for a period of over 1.5 years, she has reported persistent symptoms associated with LC-19. At her following appointment in December 2021, she noted fatigue, breathlessness, ageusia, poor appetite, weight loss, and “not feeling right.” In January 2022, she also reported poor memory, increased confusion, and being easily distracted. She was concerned she had an unnoticed stroke that was causing these symptoms. In February 2022, these symptoms persisted, and she reported left-side weakness. In April 2022, she also reported anosmia, “brain fog,” and feeling disorganized. She stated she could not describe her cognitive symptoms with words. In August 2022, she also reported generalized weakness, loss of balance, dizziness, body temperature changes, and increased disorganization. She stated she couldn't go to walk-in psychotherapy due to her disorganization.

At this time, she also began experiencing significant impairments in her daily functioning. She reported difficulties with instrumental activities of daily living, such as cooking. In September 2022, she also reported trouble with word finding. In October 2022, she also reported concern regarding her sensation of touch and vision. She reported that things felt different, and she thought her vision “easily missed things.” For example, she would not have initially seen a trash bag and would suddenly notice it was there. In January 2023, she also expressed feeling unable to drive, although once she was in the car, she could complete the task. In March 2023, she noted not being able to feel her left hand and believed she may have had a stroke to cause this. Other than fatigue and difficulty with memory, the patient did not express any of these symptoms or concerns prior to August 2021.

Her social isolation, due to her symptoms, further exacerbated her distress. She reported excessive anxiety regarding the uncertain etiology of her symptoms. She frequently expressed concern that her physicians were not doing enough to diagnose and treat her. She requested a comprehensive work-up and hospital admission. She did not meet the criteria for hospital admission and was not admitted.
diagnosis: Illness anxiety disorder (IAD)
model_thoughts:

**Data Extraction and Organization:**

**Substance Use:**

- Alcohol: In remission since age 49, occasional use (once a month) when returned at age 53

**Key Clinical Timeline:**

1. Age 49: First noted fatigue and poor memory (before COVID)
2. August 2021 (age 56): Mild COVID-19 infection
3. December 2021 onwards: Persistent symptoms including:
   - Fatigue
   - Breathlessness
   - Ageusia (loss of taste)
   - Poor appetite, weight loss
   - Cognitive complaints: memory impairment, confusion, difficulty concentrating, word-finding difficulties
   - Neurological symptoms: left-sided weakness, anosmia, loss of balance, dizziness, altered sensation, visual disturbances
   - Autonomic features: temperature dysregulation
   - Functional impact: feels unable to drive safely despite being able to complete the task once initiated, subjective sense of disorganization and "brain fog"
   - Stroke concerns: worried about unnoticed cerebrovascular event given left-hand numbness and weakness

The patient reports significant functional decline with difficulty managing instrumental activities like cooking and social withdrawal. There's marked anxiety about the underlying cause of symptoms, with repeated concerns that investigations are inadequate and requests for hospital admission despite not meeting admission criteria.

The temporal relationship to COVID-19 infection in August 2021 with subsequent persistent cognitive, olfactory, and somatic complaints suggests Long COVID as the primary medical etiology. For psychiatric coding purposes, the uncontrolled Generalized Anxiety Disorder (F41.1) is the relevant diagnosis, though this doesn't fully capture the symptom complex.

Major Depressive Disorder (F33.x) with recurrent episodes since age 39 remains partially controlled. Post-traumatic Stress Disorder (F43.10) appears stable. The cognitive impairment—including memory problems, confusion, word-finding difficulties, and disorganization—emerged post-COVID and is functionally limiting, which could warrant consideration of Mild Neurocognitive Disorder (F06.70 or F06.71) depending on whether an underlying medical condition can be documented.

Somatic Symptom Disorder warrants consideration given the multiple physical complaints, preoccupation with symptoms, and health anxiety, though the clear temporal link to COVID and documented Long COVID sequelae complicate this picture. Similarly, Illness Anxiety Disorder presents as a possibility given her preoccupation with serious illness and health-seeking behaviors, though she does have genuine somatic symptoms rather than minimal ones.

Nicotine dependence is present with ongoing daily cigarette use. Alcohol use disorder appears to be in sustained remission for approximately nine years, with only minimal occasional consumption resumed recently. Sleep disturbance has improved with medication management but remains an active concern requiring continued treatment.

The anxiety disorder presentation warrants closer examination—while generalized anxiety disorder captures much of the picture, the specific focus on health-related worries and post-COVID concerns might suggest an alternative or additional anxiety diagnosis depending on the clinical presentation. Cognitive and somatic symptoms following COVID infection could indicate a neurocognitive component, though this remains uncertain without formal neuropsychological testing. The primary clinical driver appears to be uncontrolled anxiety intertwined with health anxiety regarding her post-COVID symptoms and potential underlying medical conditions. , Moderate (F17.210) - smoking a pack daily despite awareness of health consequences. Somatic Symptom Disorder could also apply given the multiple physical complaints with disproportionate worry. There's also a history of alcohol use disorder now in remission.

The cognitive decline following COVID appears to be the most clinically significant new development, with progressive memory problems and functional decline in daily activities. Yet the anxiety disorder remains the primary driver of ongoing distress and treatment-seeking, as the patient's worry about these symptoms perpetuates the cycle. GAD is the central psychiatric diagnosis requiring immediate intervention.

The final diagnostic picture includes the anxiety disorder as primary, neurocognitive changes from the post-COVID syndrome, depressive symptoms that may be partial remission, possible PTSD features, and the tobacco dependence. The extensive somatic complaints with heightened concern about inadequate medical evaluation suggest consideration of somatic symptom pathology as well, though the established medical basis of Long COVID and the prominent cognitive syndrome may better account for the presentation. sidering the DSM-5-TR severity specifiers for MDD recurrent—mild (F33.0), moderate (F33.1), severe (F33.2), partial remission (F33.41), or full remission (F33.42). Since the case describes the depression as "partially stable," F33.41 fits best. For the neurocognitive disorder, F06.70 applies when there's no behavioral disturbance, which aligns with what's presented. I should also weigh whether an unspecified neurocognitive disorder (F09) might be more appropriate if the etiology can't be clearly established, or whether the somatic symptom focus warrants consideration of that diagnostic category instead.

My final diagnostic formulation includes generalized anxiety (F41.1), mild neurocognitive disorder due to medical condition (F06.70), recurrent major depression in partial remission (F33.41), post-traumatic stress (F43.10), and tobacco dependence (F17.210).
model_diagnosis:
1. Generalized anxiety disorder - F41.1
2. Mild neurocognitive disorder due to another medical condition, without behavioral disturbance - F06.70
3. Major depressive disorder, recurrent, in partial remission - F33.41
4. Post-traumatic stress disorder - F43.10

vignette:
The patient is a 20-year-old single man. He is unemployed and has a history of polysubstance abuse and family problems. For the past 2 years, he has used alcohol, cocaine, and medical substance (Lyrica and other medications). He has a history of social anxiety with biological symptoms, which are unresponsive to medication. He expressed low self esteem and feelings of worthlessness. He was pessimistic about the future, saying, “I don't see anything ahead for me.” He described a passive death wish, but denied having any active suicidal thoughts. He described feeling fast heartbeats, blushing, trembling, sweating, trouble catching his breath, dizziness, and panic complaints, especially when talking to people and women in specific. He also described being unable to carry out a conversation with others, feelings of being watched and laughed at, and believing that he is ugly looking. He described having these complaints since adolescence. The patient has been an addict for the past 2 years. He started with Marijuana and alcohol, and then he tried several medical drugs.
The patient talked about various upsetting memories of instances that took place during his childhood and up to his late teenage years. This included memories, such as not being given a choice or participating in decision making, his father's absence from the house due to travel, followed by the discovery of his marriage to another woman and the presence of children. His family's upbringing style is firm, authoritarian on the part of the mother, and permissive on the part of the father.
diagnosis: Social anxiety disorder (SAD) and major depressive disorder (MAD)

**Diagnostic Reasoning:**

1. **Social Anxiety Disorder (Social Phobia) - F40.10**
This is the primary diagnosis. The patient has had symptoms since adolescence (chronic, onset in typical developmental period), with marked fear in social situations, particularly when talking to people (especially women). He exhibits multiple physiological symptoms (palpitations, blushing, trembling, sweating, dyspnea, dizziness), fears being watched and laughed at, and avoids conversations. This meets DSM-5-TR criteria for Social Anxiety Disorder. The symptoms are causing significant impairment (unemployment, inability to function socially).


2. **Polysubstance Use Disorder** - The 2-year pattern of escalating use across multiple substances (alcohol, cannabis, cocaine, pregabalin) suggests moderate to severe use disorders for each. Alcohol Use Disorder (F10.20), Cannabis Use Disorder (F12.20), Cocaine Use Disorder (F14.20), and Sedative/Hypnotic/Anxiolytic Use Disorder for pregabalin (F13.20) would all apply given the addiction pattern described.

3. **Major Depressive Disorder** - The patient demonstrates persistent low mood with feelings of worthlessness, hopelessness about the future, and passive suicidal ideation, meeting criteria for depression.

4. **Body Dysmorphic Disorder** - The preoccupation with appearance ("ugly looking") warrants consideration, though this may overlap with social anxiety concerns rather than represent a distinct diagnosis.

5. **

Adjustment Disorder** - Less likely given the chronic presentation.

6. **Avoidant Personality Disorder** - F60.6 is worth considering given the long-standing pattern since adolescence, persistent low self-esteem, feelings of inadequacy, and heightened sensitivity to criticism.

The primary diagnosis is Social Anxiety Disorder (F40.10), which emerged in adolescence and encompasses the full clinical picture. Secondary diagnoses include Alcohol Use Disorder (F10.20), Cocaine Use Disorder (F14.20), and Pregabalin Use Disorder, all reflecting the substance use patterns described.

The question of whether Major Depressive Disorder should be included requires careful consideration. While the patient reports worthlessness and passive suicidal ideation, there's insufficient evidence for a full depressive episode—the symptoms of low mood and anhedonia aren't clearly documented across the required symptom threshold. The feelings of inadequacy and hopelessness may stem from the social anxiety itself rather than a separate depressive condition.

My final diagnostic formulation prioritizes Social Anxiety Disorder as the primary condition with onset in adolescence and clear symptom alignment, followed by the multiple substance use disorders and consideration of whether depressive symptoms warrant a separate diagnosis or represent secondary features of the anxiety disorder. Major Depressive Disorder rather than Cannabis Use Disorder since the mood symptoms and suicidal ideation are more clinically urgent. The polysubstance use pattern is already captured across the first four diagnoses, so prioritizing the depression makes sense given the severity of the depressive symptoms and passive suicidal ideation present.

I'm weighing whether to code this as a single episode moderate presentation or use the unspecified category since full diagnostic criteria aren't entirely confirmed. Persistent Depressive Disorder could fit given the chronic low self-esteem and long-standing nature, but the acute depressive features suggest a more recent episode. I'll use F32.9 (Unspecified Depressive Disorder) to reflect the clinical picture without overspecifying what I can't fully confirm.

My differential includes Social Anxiety Disorder, moderate Alcohol Use Disorder, Cocaine Use Disorder, and Sedative/Hypnotic/Anxiolytic Use Disorder. The passive death wish and worthlessness are significant enough that I'm prioritizing the depressive diagnosis over Cannabis Use Disorder, though that could be substituted depending on how strictly I apply the criteria.

vignette:
A 39-year-old Caucasian male presented to inpatient psychiatry after initially presenting to the emergency department with psychosis. He had been found crawling in a parking lot with several feet of intestines dragging on the ground. The patient was only responding internally during the examination, and a urine drug screen was positive only for cannabis. He received an emergent exploratory laparotomy with a partial colectomy. He stabilized medically but became briefly catatonic on day six of hospitalization, which was resolved with intravenous diazepam. On day seven, he was transferred to the inpatient psychiatry unit on a voluntary basis.

On admission to inpatient psychiatry, the patient was fully oriented and able to recall stabbing himself in the abdomen because characters in his mind told him to, having an out-of-body experience as he watched himself pull out several feet of intestines. He felt compelled to follow the voices' commands because he had guilt about his history of sexual abuse towards women. He then recalls running out of his apartment and waking up in the hospital. He endorsed paranoia and auditory hallucinations for the last 10 years but never sought treatment. He felt hopeless, yet believed his potential was infinite. He had no suicidal ideation and expressed a fear of hurting himself upon returning home if the voices persisted.

He had never been diagnosed with a psychiatric illness or received treatment, but he did see a psychiatrist at age 17 after he was charged with indecent exposure. He recalled periods in his life when he had little need for sleep, had racing thoughts, and felt that signs and advertisements were speaking directly to him. His social history was notable for heavy cannabis use beginning at age 18. He was a daily user for 5-6 years and began experiencing paranoia and auditory hallucinations. Despite quitting for two years, the psychotic symptoms persisted, and he reported currently using cannabis 3-4 days per week. He also had a history of trauma and was emotionally and physically abused by his father who had alcohol use disorder.

On a physical exam, the patient had normal speech and appearance, an expansive affect, and poor insight. He endorsed auditory hallucinations of male voices that were commanding and feelings of paranoia.
diagnosis: Schizoaffective disorder
model_thoughts:
Let me analyze this clinical case vignette systematically to arrive at the most appropriate DSM-5-TR diagnoses.

**Data Extraction and Organization:**

Demographics:
- 39-year-old Caucasian male

Presenting Problem:
- Found crawling in parking lot with intestines exposed after self-inflicted abdominal wound
- Self-evisceration in response to command auditory hallucinations
- Brief catatonic episode on day 6, resolved with IV diazepam

Current Mental Status:
- Fully oriented on admission to psychiatry
- Expansive affect
- Normal speech and appearance
- Poor insight
- Active auditory hallucinations (male, commanding voices)
- Paranoia
- Expressed fear of hurting himself if voices persist
- Felt hopeless yet believed potential was infinite (contradictory cognitions suggesting possible mixed features)
- No current suicidal ideation

Psychiatric History:
- Never formally diagnosed or treated
- Saw psychiatrist at age 17 after being charged with indecent exposure
- 10-year history of paranoia and auditory hallucinations (since approximately age 29)
- Reported periods of:
  - Little need for sleep
  - Racing thoughts
  - Ideas of reference (signs and advertisements speaking to him)
- History of sexual abuse towards women (perpetrator)

Substance Use:
- Heavy cannabis use starting at age 18
- Daily use for 5-6 years
- Quit for 2 years but psychotic symptoms persisted
- Currently using 3-4 days per week
- Urine drug screen positive for cannabis

Trauma History:
- Emotional and physical abuse by father with alcohol use disorder

Timeline of Symptoms:
- Age 17: Indecent exposure charge, saw psychiatrist
- Age 18: Started heavy cannabis use
- Psychosis began during heavy cannabis use (age ~18-24)
- Symptoms persisted during 2-year abstinence period


- Current: 10-year history of paranoia and auditory hallucinations

**Diagnostic Reasoning:**

The persistence of hallucinations and paranoia across a 2-year period without cannabis use rules out substance-induced psychosis as the primary diagnosis. This points toward an independent psychotic disorder. The combination of persistent psychotic symptoms alongside mood disturbance—expansive affect with contradictory hopelessness and grandiose beliefs—suggests I need to differentiate between schizoaffective disorder and schizophrenia. The presence of mood episodes interspersed with psychotic symptoms, particularly the mixed affective presentation, warrants careful consideration of schizoaffective disorder as the primary diagnosis. after cannabis use, combined with severe psychotic symptoms and a recent serious self-harm attempt, indicates he's continuing to use despite clear psychological harm—meeting criteria for at least moderate cannabis use disorder. I should also consider catatonia (he had a brief episode responsive to diazepam), possible antisocial personality features given his history of indecent exposure and sexual abuse, and PTSD from childhood trauma. The most likely primary diagnosis remains schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type, given the 10+ year course of psychotic symptoms alongside distinct mood episodes featuring decreased need for sleep, racing thoughts, and current expansive affect. cannabis abstinence rules out cannabis-induced psychotic disorder as primary. The chronic psychotic symptoms combined with episodic mood disturbance point toward schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type. His current expansive affect and historical manic episodes support this presentation. Cannabis use disorder is clearly established given the continued use despite substantial harm. The behavioral history—sexual offenses and indecent exposure—suggests antisocial personality features.

The most likely primary diagnosis is Schizoaffective Disorder, Bipolar Type, with Cannabis Use Disorder, Moderate to Severe, and Antisocial Personality Disorder as additional diagnoses. Schizophrenia and Bipolar I Disorder with Psychotic Features remain in the differential. diagnosis if psychotic symptoms predominate over mood episodes.

PTSD seems less likely without clear intrusive symptoms or avoidance patterns documented. I'm leaning toward Bipolar I with psychotic features as a strong alternative, though the 10-year duration of psychosis makes schizoaffective disorder more fitting.

My final diagnostic ranking: Schizoaffective Disorder, Bipolar Type remains primary, with Cannabis Use Disorder (need to determine if moderate or severe based on frequency and impact), Antisocial Personality Disorder supported by the behavioral history, and Bipolar I Disorder with psychotic features as a key differential. For cannabis severity, the reported use pattern of several days weekly suggests at least moderate severity. The cannabis-induced psychotic disorder diagnosis seems less likely given the persistence of symptoms during two years without use. For the final differential, schizoaffective disorder bipolar type appears most consistent with the presentation of mood episodes alongside psychotic features. Cannabis use disorder is moderate severity based on the pattern of continued use despite psychiatric consequences. Antisocial personality disorder traits are evident in the behavioral history, and bipolar I disorder with psychotic features should remain in the differential given the manic episodes documented.

4. Antisocial Personality Disorder - F60.2
5. Bipolar I Disorder, Current Episode Manic, with Psychotic Features - F31.2

vignette:
A 39-year-old Indonesian woman complained of having had two seizures of 10-min duration. When the hand spasms are stiff, the eyes glance up, and the mouth is foaming and wetting the bed. After the seizure, the patient is unconscious. The patient had no history of previous seizures. The patient also has a history of SLE, diagnosed 5 years ago with high titer ANA and she received cyclophosphamide therapy. The patient had no experience of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, stroke, and tumor.

Her clinical condition showed facial and lingual palsy with central type on the right. Laboratory abnormalities included normochromic anemia (hemoglobin 10.6 g/dL, hematocrit 32.2%, MCV of 88 fL, MCH of 29 pg, MCHC of 32.9 g/dL) with slightly decreased platelet level (124,000 cell/µL), slightly decrease of albumin level (3.4 g/dL), the elevation of erythrocyte sedimentation rate (72 mm/hr), and slightly decrease of potassium (3.4 nmol/L). Meanwhile, PT/APTT, AST, ALT, bilirubin, BUN, creatinine, glucose, iron, sodium, and chloride levels were normal. Urinalysis examination showed proteinuria (+2), hematuria (+1), an increased albumin/creatinine ratio of ≥300 mg/g, and a protein/creatinine ratio of ≥0.5 mg/g. Blood gas analysis showed metabolic acidosis (pH of 7.34, pCO2 of 31 mmHg, HCO3 of 16.7 mmol/L, and base excess of −9.1 mmol/L).

Immunology results show an increase of procalcitonin (0.32 ng/mL), ferritin (427.6 mg/dL), positive ana test (ANA test ELISA index 392.66), low level of C3 (19 mg/dL) and C4 6 (mg/dL), elevated IgG anticardiolipin (91.10 GPLU/mL). Antinuclear antibody indirect immunofluorescence (ANA IF) positive using cytobead ANA with a homogenous pattern and cytoplasmic dense fine speckled titer 1/80 (Figure 1). In addition, the dsDNA test was positive (Figure 2). ANA profile was examined using euroline ANA profile three panels plus DFS70 showed strong positive for antinucleosome (++), antihistones (+++), anti-AMA-M2 (+++), and borderline for anti-RNP/Sm, PM-Scl100 (PM 100), and anti-dsDNA and negative for anti-Sm, SSA, Ro-52, SSB, Scl-70, Jo-1, centromere B, PCNA, and ribosomal protein (RIB).
diagnosis: Neuropsychiatric systemic lupus erythematosus (NPSLE)
model_thoughts:
Let me analyze this clinical case vignette carefully.

**Data Extraction and Organization:**

Demographics:
- 39-year-old Indonesian woman

Chief Complaint:
- Two seizures of 10-minute duration
- Characteristics: hand spasms (stiff), eyes glancing up, foaming at mouth, bed wetting
- Post-ictal unconsciousness
- No prior seizure history

Medical History:
- Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) diagnosed 5 years ago
- High titer ANA
- Treated with cyclophosphamide
- No diabetes, hypertension, stroke, or tumor

Physical/Neurological Findings:
- Right-sided facial and lingual palsy (central type) - suggests CNS involvement

Laboratory Findings:
- Normochromic anemia (Hgb 10.6)
- Mild thrombocytopenia (124,000)
- Low albumin (3.4)
- Elevated ESR (72 mm/hr) - inflammation marker
- Low potassium (3.4)
- Normal: PT/APTT, liver function, renal function, glucose, iron, electrolytes

Urinalysis:
- Proteinuria (+2)
- Hematuria (+1)
- Elevated albumin/creatinine ratio (≥300 mg/g)
- Elevated protein/creatinine ratio (≥0.5 mg/g)
- Suggestive of lupus nephritis

Blood Gas:
- Metabolic acidosis

Immunology:
- Elevated procalcitonin (0.32 ng/mL) - possible infection/inflammation
- Elevated ferritin (427.6)
- Strongly positive ANA (ELISA index 392.66)
- Low complement C3 (19 mg/dL) and C4 (6 mg/dL) - active lupus


- Elevated IgG anticardiolipin (91.10 GPLU/mL) - antiphospholipid antibodies present
- ANA IF shows homogenous pattern with positive dsDNA, antinucleosome, antihistones, and anti-AMA-M2; borderline anti-RNP/Sm and PM-Scl100

**Diagnostic Reasoning:**

This presentation fits neuropsychiatric SLE (NPSLE). The patient has established SLE with new-onset seizures, suggesting CNS lupus involvement rather than a primary seizure disorder.

The clinical picture includes recent-onset seizures, facial and lingual weakness indicating central nervous system involvement, serologically active disease with depressed complement levels and elevated dsDNA antibodies, evidence of renal involvement, and circulating antiphospholipid antibodies. These findings point to lupus cerebritis as the underlying etiology.

In DSM-5-TR terms, this would be classified as a mental disorder due to another medical condition, since the neurological manifestations stem directly from SLE pathology. The seizures and focal neurological deficits represent secondary CNS involvement from lupus rather than a primary neuropsychiatric condition. When the specific psychiatric syndrome isn't clearly delineated beyond the seizure activity itself, unspecified mental disorder due to another medical condition becomes the most fitting diagnostic category. Due to Another Medical Condition (F09)** - This applies when the psychiatric presentation doesn't clearly fit other diagnostic categories. Given the CNS involvement from SLE, the seizures and neurological manifestations could warrant this diagnosis if psychiatric symptoms emerge.

I should also consider whether cognitive changes from the CNS lupus might meet criteria for Major or Mild Neurocognitive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition, particularly if there's documented impairment beyond the acute seizure episodes. The focal neurological deficit and post-ictal states suggest significant brain involvement that could have lasting cognitive consequences. However, the vignette emphasizes the seizures and acute neurological presentation rather than established cognitive decline, so this may be premature without further assessment.

The core challenge here is that seizures themselves aren't psychiatric diagnoses in DSM-5-TR, but the underlying SLE causing CNS dysfunction does warrant psychiatric coding when neuropsychiatric symptoms manifest. The most fitting options appear to be F06.8 for the neuropsychiatric manifestations of lupus, or F05 if acute delirium or altered consciousness beyond post-ictal states is documented. F02.80/F02.81 becomes relevant only if cognitive impairment is clearly established. Since the case presentation centers on acute neurological events rather than primary psychiatric symptoms, the psychiatric diagnosis would essentially capture the brain involvement from the underlying medical condition. The seizures represent a neurological manifestation of CNS lupus, while psychiatric symptoms would need to be specifically identified—such as cognitive dysfunction, mood disturbance, psychosis, anxiety, or altered consciousness. Since the case primarily documents seizures and post-ictal unconsciousness without clearly delineated psychiatric symptoms, F06.8 remains the most fitting diagnosis for neuropsychiatric lupus, with F05 capturing the post-ictal delirium and F09 serving as a fallback when the presentation lacks sufficient specificity for more precise classification. Other Specified Mental Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition best captures the neuropsychiatric manifestations of SLE affecting the CNS. Delirium Due to Another Medical Condition applies to the post-ictal altered consciousness. Major Neurocognitive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition could be relevant if cognitive impairment from CNS lupus is present. The case is primarily neurological rather than psychiatric—seizures and focal neurological deficits are the core features, with psychiatric symptoms secondary to the underlying medical condition. . **F09 Unspecified Mental Disorder** - when the specific psychiatric syndrome isn't clearly delineated. **F06.30 Mood Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition, with depressive features** - since mood disturbances are common in NPSLE.

However, I'm reconsidering the approach. The clinical picture centers on seizures, post-ictal states, and focal neurological deficits with active SLE and CNS involvement—the psychiatric component is secondary to the neurological manifestations. Post-ictal unconsciousness is transient and seizure-related rather than true delirium. Using the DSM-5-TR framework, I'd apply the "Due to Another Medical Condition" specifier for any psychiatric symptoms arising from SLE's CNS effects. Since psychiatric symptoms aren't prominently featured in this presentation, F06.8 Other Specified Mental Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition seems most appropriate as the primary diagnosis.

vignette:
A 50-year-old male from Nuwakot (nearby Kathmandu), married and unemployed, presented with a history of regular alcohol usage, meeting the ICD-10 diagnostic criteria for alcohol dependence over the last 20 years. The Alcohol Use Disorder Identification Test (AUDIT) score of the patient was 30, indicating severe alcohol dependence. He had delirium tremens twice in the last 4 years. In the past, abstinence was prompted by a cultural factor (mourning of a brother) and a physical factor (pancreatitis). This time, the reason for abstinence was the COVID-19 lockdown. Following the lockdown, the patient was forced to stop alcohol due to its unavailability and inaccessibility. Due to movement constraints, family members had trouble getting treatment during the early withdrawal period. After three days of abstinence, the patient started having symptoms of agitation, decreased sleep, tremors of the hand and body, decreased awareness of the surroundings, visual hallucinations, and was hearing frightening voices. While having these symptoms, the patient tried to jump from the house (but was stopped by family members) and later inflicted a cut injury over the neck with a kitchen knife, stating that it was better to die on own than to die from others. A 3∗1 cm horizontal laceration in the anterior neck was sustained.

He was rushed to Tribhuvan University Teaching Hospital (TUTH) for an emergency. He was attended by the emergency, otorhinolaryngology, and psychiatry teams. The mental status examination (MSE) at admission showed that the patient had psychomotor agitation, sweating, tremors of both hands and body, disorientation to time and place, impaired attention and concentration, impaired immediate recall, and recent memory. The Clinical Institute Withdrawal Assessment Alcohol Scale Revised (CIWA-AR) score was 45, indicating severe withdrawal. The initial investigations revealed thrombocytopenia (9 lac/cu.mm), alcoholic hepatitis (total bilirubin—1.4 mg/dL, direct bilirubin—0.6 mg/dL, SGOT—269 IU/L, SGPT—56 IU/L), hyponatremia (123 mEq/L). However, other electrolytes, random sugar, serology markers, urine routine examination, electrocardiogram, and thyroid profile were all within the normal range. The COVID-19 PCR was negative. The blood sodium level was normalized on the next day of admission. A provisional diagnosis of alcohol withdrawal delirium was made based on the findings.
diagnosis: Alcohol dependence syndrome; withdrawal state with delirium without convulsions (F10.40)
model_thoughts:
Let me analyze this clinical case vignette carefully to arrive at accurate DSM-5-TR diagnoses.

**Data Extraction and Organization:**

Demographics:
- 50-year-old male
- Married, unemployed
- From Nuwakot, Nepal

Substance Use History:
- 20 years of regular alcohol use
- Meets ICD-10 criteria for alcohol dependence
- AUDIT score: 30 (severe alcohol dependence)
- History of delirium tremens twice in past 4 years
- Previous periods of abstinence due to cultural factors (mourning) and medical issues (pancreatitis)

Current Presentation Timeline:
- Forced abstinence due to COVID-19 lockdown (unavailability of alcohol)
- After 3 days of abstinence, developed withdrawal symptoms

Symptoms of Current Episode:
- Agitation
- Decreased sleep
- Tremors of hand and body
- Decreased awareness of surroundings (disorientation)
- Visual hallucinations
- Auditory hallucinations (frightening voices)
- Suicidal behavior: attempted to jump from house, self-inflicted neck laceration with knife
- Stated "better to die on own than to die from others"

Mental Status Examination:
- Psychomotor agitation
- Sweating
- Tremors (both hands and body)
- Disorientation to time and place
- Impaired attention and concentration
- Impaired immediate recall and recent memory

Clinical Scales:
- CIWA-AR score: 45 (severe withdrawal)

Medical Findings:
- Thrombocytopenia
- Alcoholic hepatitis (elevated SGOT)
- Hyponatremia (123 mEq/L) - normalized next day
- Negative COVID-19 PCR
- Other labs normal

**Diagnostic Reasoning:**

1. **Alcohol Withdrawal Delirium (Delirium Tremens)** - This is clearly the primary diagnosis:


The clinical picture fits the classic presentation: onset 3 days after stopping heavy alcohol use, with disorientation to time and place, visual and auditory hallucinations, autonomic hyperactivity (tremors, sweating, agitation), and cognitive impairment affecting attention and memory. The CIWA-AR score of 45 indicates severe withdrawal, and his prior episodes of delirium tremens strengthen this diagnosis. DSM-5-TR code: F10.231

2. **Alcohol Use Disorder, Severe** - Established by his 20-year drinking history, AUDIT score of 30, and continued use despite significant consequences including previous medical complications and current suicidal behavior. The diagnosis meets criteria for severe presentation.

3. **Suicidal Behavior/Self-Harm in Context of Delirium** - He attempted to jump from the house and inflicted a laceration to his neck while expressing suicidal intent ("better to die on own than to die from others"). This behavior occurred during the acute delirium episode, suggesting the altered mental state significantly contributed to the self-harm risk.

The hallucinations and suicidal ideation are manifestations of the delirium itself rather than separate diagnoses. I should also consider whether alcohol-induced psychotic or mood disorders apply here. The visual and auditory hallucinations are present, but they're embedded within the withdrawal delirium rather than representing a distinct psychotic disorder. Similarly, while suicidal statements could indicate depression, they're occurring in the context of acute delirium without sufficient evidence for an independent mood disorder diagnosis. Other factors like the mild hyponatremia may have contributed to the delirium but resolved quickly, and the alcoholic hepatitis requires monitoring but doesn't change the primary psychiatric coding.

For the final diagnosis, alcohol withdrawal delirium is the primary condition. The underlying alcohol use disorder is severe and should be coded separately. I need to determine the correct DSM-5-TR code—F10.231 indicates alcohol dependence with withdrawal delirium, while F10.232 indicates withdrawal with perceptual disturbances. Since this patient presents with both delirium and hallucinations, I should verify which code best captures the full clinical picture.

For secondary diagnoses, the severe alcohol use disorder could be coded as F10.20 to document the chronic underlying condition, though there may be some redundancy with the primary withdrawal code. The suicidal ideation appears contextual to the delirium rather than a separate mood disorder, so coding an alcohol-induced depressive disorder lacks sufficient evidence. I should consider whether any additional alcohol-related diagnoses would meaningfully capture aspects of the presentation.

Looking at the DSM-5-TR coding structure, F10.231 (alcohol withdrawal delirium with moderate to severe use disorder) is the most appropriate primary diagnosis since it encompasses both the acute withdrawal state with delirium and the severity level of the underlying substance use pattern. The perceptual disturbances are already captured within this code.

For secondary diagnoses, I should consider what additional conditions might be present. The severe use disorder component is actually embedded in the "2" of F10.231, so listing a separate AUD code would be redundant. Instead, I need to think about other clinical presentations that could coexist—such as whether there are mood or psychotic features that warrant separate coding, or if there are medical complications from the withdrawal state itself that should be documented. The suicidal ideation appears secondary to the delirium and hallucinations rather than indicative of a primary mood disorder, and there's no evidence of personality pathology in the presentation.

My final diagnostic formulation centers on alcohol withdrawal delirium as the primary condition, with severe alcohol use disorder as the underlying chronic disorder. The hallucinations—both visual and auditory—warrant coding as alcohol-induced psychotic symptoms, even though they're occurring within the delirium context. The withdrawal itself should be documented, though I need to verify whether to code uncomplicated or complicated withdrawal given the delirium is already captured separately.

I'm also considering whether other medical conditions could be contributing to this presentation, particularly given the need for a comprehensive differential diagnosis rather than just variations of alcohol-related disorders.

Hyponatremia from liver disease or hepatic encephalopathy could theoretically produce delirium, but the clinical picture—with symptom onset three days after stopping alcohol and the characteristic progression—points much more directly to withdrawal syndrome. The hallucinations and autonomic instability fit the withdrawal delirium pattern rather than a primary psychotic disorder, though substance-induced psychosis remains in the differential. Similarly, while the suicidal ideation might suggest a mood disorder, it appears secondary to the delirium and perceptual disturbances rather than representing primary depression.

The most likely diagnosis is alcohol withdrawal delirium given the temporal relationship to cessation, disorientation, memory problems, visual and auditory hallucinations, tremor, diaphoresis, and elevated CIWA-AR score. Severe alcohol use disorder is the underlying condition. Medical causes like hyponatremia and hepatic dysfunction should be ruled out, though lab values have normalized and the clinical presentation aligns with withdrawal. Alcohol-induced psychotic disorder with hallucinations could be considered if emphasizing the perceptual symptoms, though the full delirium picture makes withdrawal delirium the primary diagnosis. codes. The ICD-10-F codes for alcohol-related conditions include F10.231 for alcohol dependence with withdrawal delirium, F10.232 for withdrawal with perceptual disturbances, F10.251 for alcohol-induced psychotic disorder with hallucinations, and F10.259 for unspecified alcohol-induced psychotic disorder. F05 covers delirium from known physiological conditions. Given this framework, the primary diagnosis should be F10.231, with consideration of F10.251 if hallucinations persist beyond the acute withdrawal phase.

1. Alcohol withdrawal delirium - F10.231
2. Alcohol use disorder, severe - F10.20
3. Alcohol dependence with withdrawal with perceptual disturbances - F10.232
4. Delirium due to other medical condition - F05
5. Alcohol-induced psychotic disorder with hallucinations - F10.251

vignette:
A 40-year-old male, separated, non-skilled worker from Dhading presented with a history of alcohol consumption for around 20 years and met the criteria for alcohol dependence syndrome for the last 10 years. His AUDIT score was 24, indicating moderate to severe alcohol dependence. The patient's usual work was disrupted as a result of COVID-19, causing his alcohol relapse. The patient drank alcohol from local neighborhood stores. As a result of the COVID-19 lockdown, shop owners stopped preparing and selling alcohol entirely, resulting in forced abstinence. Following two days of abstinence, he began to claim that the 10–15 individuals were after him and were planning to hurt him. In full consciousness, the patient could hear these voices. The patient fled to hide at a relative's residence nearby. Later, the patient inflicted a cut injury with a kitchen knife, claiming that his act would hold those who followed him accountable for his death. Unlike in the previous case, symptoms arose while the patient was conscious and able to recall all of the events. A 4∗1 cm cut in the anteriolateral neck was sustained.

At the time of admission, the MSE showed that the patient was restless, had tremors of the hands and body, was sweating, was oriented to time, place, and person, his attention and concentration were intact, and his CIWA-AR score was 35, indicating severe withdrawal. The initial investigations revealed alcoholic hepatitis (total bilirubin—1.8 mg/dL, SGOT—356 IU/L, SGPT—231 IU/L), Hypokalemia (3.3 mEq/L), USG abdomen and pelvis showed-moderate fatty liver. However, other electrolytes, random sugar, serology markers, urine routine examination, electrocardiogram, and thyroid profile were all within the normal range. The COVID-19 PCR was negative.
diagnosis: Alcohol Dependence Syndrome — Psychotic Disorder: Mixed: hallucination and delusion (F10.56)

The vignette emphasizes that:
